oneLeg.name: Long Call
oneLeg.description: Simplest bullish strategy. Buys the right, but not the obligation, to purchase the underlying asset at the strike price before expiration. Used when expecting a significant rise in the underlying price. It provides unlimited upside potential with risk limited to the premium paid.

greeksImpact.gamma: Positive (highest ATM)

oneLeg.example: Buy 1 MES JUN13 5980 Call for 83.00 (Ask). Break-even: 5980 + 83.00 = 6063.00

oneLeg.name: Short Put
oneLeg.description: Collects premium by selling the obligation to buy the underlying asset if it falls below the strike price. Profitable if the underlying stays above the strike price. Often used to generate income or acquire shares at a discount. High potential risk if the price drops significantly below the strike.

greeksImpact.gamma: Negative (most negative ATM)

oneLeg.example: Sell 1 MES JUN13 5970 Put for 104.50 (Bid). Break-even: 5970 - 104.50 = 5865.50

oneLeg.name: Short Call (Naked)
oneLeg.description: Collects premium by selling the obligation to sell the underlying asset if it rises above the strike price. Profitable if the underlying stays below the strike price. This is a high-risk strategy as the potential loss is theoretically unlimited if the price rises significantly. Typically only for experienced traders with margin.

greeksImpact.gamma: Negative (most negative ATM)

oneLeg.example: Sell 1 MES JUN13 5970 Call for 83.25 (Bid). Break-even: 5970 + 83.25 = 6053.25

oneLeg.name: Long Put
oneLeg.description: Simplest bearish strategy. Buys the right, but not the obligation, to sell the underlying asset at the strike price before expiration. Used when expecting a significant fall in the underlying price. Limits risk to the premium paid while offering substantial profit potential if the price drops sharply.

greeksImpact.gamma: Positive (highest ATM)

oneLeg.example: Buy 1 MES JUN13 5970 Put for 109.50 (Ask). Break-even: 5970 - 109.50 = 5860.50

oneLeg.name: Covered Call
oneLeg.description: Selling a call option against shares of the underlying stock already owned (100 shares per call contract). Generates income (premium) and provides limited protection against a price decline. It caps the upside profit potential at the call strike price. Note: This strategy is typically used with stocks, not futures like MES, and requires owning the underlying asset equivalent.

greeksImpact.delta: Reduced positive delta compared to stock alone
greeksImpact.gamma: Slightly negative
greeksImpact.theta: Positive (benefits from time decay of the sold call)

oneLeg.maxProfit: Strike Price + Premium Received - Stock Purchase Price
oneLeg.maxLoss: Stock Purchase Price - Premium Received (down to zero)
oneLeg.example: Hypothetical: Own 100 shares of XYZ bought at $100. Sell 1 XYZ 105 Call for $1.50. Break-even: 100 - 1.50 = 98.50. Max Profit at/above 105: (105 - 100) + 1.50 = 6.50.

oneLeg.name: Cash-Secured Put
oneLeg.description: Selling a put option and setting aside enough cash to buy the underlying shares if assigned. A way to potentially buy shares at a discount (the strike price) while collecting premium. Similar profit/loss profile to a Covered Call, but doesn't require owning stock upfront. Risk is owning the underlying if assigned below the strike.
construction: Hold cash equal to Strike Price * Contract Multiplier (e.g., 100 for US stocks, 5 for MES)

greeksImpact.delta: Positive (similar to long stock up to strike)
greeksImpact.gamma: Negative

oneLeg.maxLoss: Strike Price - Premium Received (down to zero if assigned and underlying goes to zero)
oneLeg.example: Sell 1 MES JUN13 5970 Put for 104.50 (Bid), conceptually holding cash/margin equivalent to 5970 * 5 = 29850. Break-even: 5970 - 104.50 = 5865.50.

oneLeg.name: Protective Put
oneLeg.description: Buying a put option against shares of the underlying stock already owned. Provides insurance against a price decline below the put strike price, limiting the potential loss. The cost is the premium paid for the put.

greeksImpact.delta: Reduced positive delta compared to stock alone
greeksImpact.gamma: Slightly positive

oneLeg.maxLoss: Stock Purchase Price - Put Strike Price + Premium Paid
oneLeg.example: Hypothetical: Own 100 shares of XYZ bought at $100. Buy 1 XYZ 95 Put for $1.80. Break-even: 100 + 1.80 = 101.80. Max Loss: 100 - 95 + 1.80 = 6.80 (per share).

twoLeg.name: Bull Call Spread (Vertical Debit)
twoLeg.description: A defined-risk, defined-profit bullish strategy. Buys a call at a lower strike (K1) and sells a call at a higher strike (K2) with the same expiration. Used when expecting a moderate rise in the underlying price. Cheaper than a long call, but profit potential is capped.

greeksImpact.delta: Positive (less than a single long call)
greeksImpact.gamma: Generally positive below K2, negative above K2
greeksImpact.theta: Generally negative (loses value with time), especially if ATM
greeksImpact.vega: Generally negative (loses value with increased volatility), especially if strikes are close

twoLeg.maxProfit: Difference between strikes (K2 - K1) - Net Debit Paid

twoLeg.name: Bear Put Spread (Vertical Debit)
twoLeg.description: A defined-risk, defined-profit bearish strategy. Buys a put at a higher strike (K2) and sells a put at a lower strike (K1) with the same expiration. Used when expecting a moderate decline in the underlying price. Cheaper than a long put, but profit potential is capped.

greeksImpact.delta: Negative (less than a single long put)
greeksImpact.gamma: Generally positive below K1, negative above K1
greeksImpact.theta: Generally negative (loses value with time), especially if ATM
greeksImpact.vega: Generally negative (loses value with increased volatility), especially if strikes are close

twoLeg.maxProfit: Difference between strikes (K2 - K1) - Net Debit Paid

twoLeg.name: Bear Call Spread (Vertical Credit)
twoLeg.description: A defined-risk strategy that profits if the underlying stays below the short call strike (K1). Sells a call at a lower strike (K1) and buys a call at a higher strike (K2) with the same expiration for protection. Used when expecting a moderate decline or neutral movement. Entered for a net credit.

greeksImpact.delta: Negative (less negative than a single short call)
greeksImpact.gamma: Generally negative below K1, positive above K1

twoLeg.maxLoss: Difference between strikes (K2 - K1) - Net Credit Received

twoLeg.name: Bull Put Spread (Vertical Credit)
twoLeg.description: A defined-risk strategy that profits if the underlying stays above the long put strike (K1). Sells a put at a higher strike (K2) and buys a put at a lower strike (K1) with the same expiration for protection. Used when expecting a moderate rise or neutral movement. Entered for a net credit.

greeksImpact.delta: Positive (less positive than a single short put)
greeksImpact.gamma: Generally negative below K2, positive above K2

twoLeg.maxLoss: Difference between strikes (K2 - K1) - Net Credit Received

twoLeg.name: Long Straddle
twoLeg.description: Buying a call and a put with the same strike price (K) and expiration date. Profits from a significant price move in either direction, whether up or down. Used when expecting a large move but uncertain of the direction. Max loss is the total premium paid.

greeksImpact.gamma: Strongly positive (increases directional exposure as price moves)
greeksImpact.theta: Strongly negative (loses value rapidly with time decay)
greeksImpact.vega: Strongly positive (benefits significantly from increased volatility)

twoLeg.maxProfit: Unlimited (Up); Strike Price - Net Debit Paid (Down)
twoLeg.breakeven: Lower: Strike K - Net Debit Paid; Upper: Strike K + Net Debit Paid
twoLeg.example: Buy 1 MES JUN13 5970 Call for 88.25 (Ask), Buy 1 MES JUN13 5970 Put for 109.50 (Ask). Net Debit: 88.25 + 109.50 = 197.75. Lower Break-even: 5970 - 197.75 = 5772.25. Upper Break-even: 5970 + 197.75 = 6167.75.

twoLeg.name: Short Straddle
twoLeg.description: Selling a call and a put with the same strike price (K) and expiration date. Profits from time decay and low volatility, provided the underlying price stays close to the strike. Max profit is the total premium received. Risk is potentially unlimited, making this a strategy for experienced traders comfortable with significant risk management.

greeksImpact.gamma: Strongly negative (directional exposure increases rapidly as price moves away)
greeksImpact.theta: Strongly positive (benefits significantly from time decay)
greeksImpact.vega: Strongly negative (loses value significantly with increased volatility)

twoLeg.maxLoss: Unlimited (Up); Strike Price - Net Credit Received (Down to zero underlying price)
twoLeg.breakeven: Lower: Strike K - Net Credit Received; Upper: Strike K + Net Credit Received
twoLeg.example: Sell 1 MES JUN13 5970 Call for 83.25 (Bid), Sell 1 MES JUN13 5970 Put for 104.50 (Bid). Net Credit: 83.25 + 104.50 = 187.75. Lower Break-even: 5970 - 187.75 = 5782.25. Upper Break-even: 5970 + 187.75 = 6157.75.

twoLeg.name: Long Strangle
twoLeg.description: Buying an OTM put (K1) and an OTM call (K2) with the same expiration date (K1 < K2). Cheaper than a straddle but requires a larger price move to break even. Profits from significant volatility and price movement outside the range defined by the strikes. Max loss is limited to the premium paid.
twoLeg.notes: K1 < K2. Both strikes are typically OTM relative to the current price.

greeksImpact.delta: Near zero at initiation (slightly positive if K2 is less OTM than K1, or vice-versa)
greeksImpact.gamma: Positive (increases directional exposure as price moves away from center)

twoLeg.maxProfit: Unlimited (Up); Lower Strike K1 - Net Debit Paid (Down to zero underlying price)
twoLeg.breakeven: Lower: K1 - Net Debit Paid; Upper: K2 + Net Debit Paid
twoLeg.example: Buy 1 MES JUN13 5960 Put for 105.00 (Ask), Buy 1 MES JUN13 5990 Call for 78.00 (Ask). Net Debit: 105.00 + 78.00 = 183.00. Lower Break-even: 5960 - 183.00 = 5777.00. Upper Break-even: 5990 + 183.00 = 6173.00.

twoLeg.name: Short Strangle
twoLeg.description: Selling an OTM put (K1) and an OTM call (K2) with the same expiration date (K1 < K2). Profits from time decay and the underlying staying between the two strikes. Offers more room for the price to move than a short straddle but receives less premium. Risk is potentially unlimited, suitable for experienced traders expecting low volatility.
twoLeg.notes: K1 < K2. Both strikes are typically OTM relative to the current price.

greeksImpact.delta: Near zero at initiation (slightly negative if K1 is less OTM than K2, or vice-versa)
greeksImpact.gamma: Negative (directional exposure increases as price moves away from center)
greeksImpact.vega: Negative (loses value significantly with increased volatility)

twoLeg.maxLoss: Unlimited (Up); Lower Strike K1 - Net Credit Received (Down to zero underlying price)
twoLeg.breakeven: Lower: K1 - Net Credit Received; Upper: K2 + Net Credit Received
twoLeg.example: Sell 1 MES JUN13 5960 Put for 100.00 (Bid), Sell 1 MES JUN13 5990 Call for 73.00 (Bid). Net Credit: 100.00 + 73.00 = 173.00. Lower Break-even: 5960 - 173.00 = 5787.00. Upper Break-even: 5990 + 173.00 = 6163.00.

twoLeg.name: Long Call Calendar Spread
twoLeg.outlook: Neutral to Moderately Bullish (Time Decay & Volatility)
twoLeg.description: Sells a near-term call and buys a longer-term call with the same strike price. Profits from the faster time decay of the near-term option compared to the longer-term option. Benefits from the underlying price staying near the strike and potentially from an increase in implied volatility of the longer-dated option. Risk is limited to the debit paid.
twoLeg.notes: Requires options in the same underlying with different expiration dates but the same strike price.

greeksImpact.delta: Near zero (neutral) if strike is ATM, slightly positive if strike is OTM call side
greeksImpact.gamma: Typically negative
greeksImpact.vega: Positive (benefits from increased volatility, especially in the longer-dated option)

twoLeg.maxProfit: Limited (achieved if underlying is exactly at strike K at near expiry)
twoLeg.breakeven: Two break-even points, one below and one above the strike K.
twoLeg.example: Hypothetical (Requires different expiries): Buy 1 MES JUL18 5970 Call for $150, Sell 1 MES JUN13 5970 Call for 83.25 (Mid). Net Debit: 150 - 83.25 = 66.75.

twoLeg.name: Long Put Calendar Spread
twoLeg.outlook: Neutral to Moderately Bearish (Time Decay & Volatility)
twoLeg.description: Sells a near-term put and buys a longer-term put with the same strike price. Profits from the faster time decay of the near-term option. Benefits from the underlying price staying near the strike and potentially from an increase in implied volatility. Risk is limited to the debit paid.
twoLeg.notes: Requires options in the same underlying with different expiration dates but the same strike price.

greeksImpact.delta: Near zero (neutral) if strike is ATM, slightly negative if strike is OTM put side
greeksImpact.gamma: Typically negative

twoLeg.maxProfit: Limited (achieved if underlying is exactly at strike K at near expiry)
twoLeg.breakeven: Two break-even points, one below and one above the strike K.
twoLeg.example: Hypothetical (Requires different expiries): Buy 1 MES JUL18 5970 Put for $160, Sell 1 MES JUN13 5970 Put for 104.50 (Mid). Net Debit: 160 - 104.50 = 55.50.

threeLeg.name: Long Call Butterfly
threeLeg.description: A defined-risk strategy expecting the price to pin the middle strike (K2) at expiration. Profits from low volatility within a specific range around K2. Constructed with three calls (K1 < K2 < K3) where K2 is typically equidistant from K1 and K3. Entered for a net debit.
threeLeg.notes: Strikes K1, K2, K3 are typically equidistant.

greeksImpact.gamma: Initially negative, becomes positive as price approaches K2, negative again beyond K2
greeksImpact.theta: Positive (benefits from time decay) when price is near K2, negative further away

threeLeg.maxProfit: Middle Strike (K2) - Lower Strike (K1) - Net Debit Paid
threeLeg.breakeven: Lower: K1 + Net Debit Paid; Upper: K3 - Net Debit Paid

threeLeg.name: Long Put Butterfly
threeLeg.description: Similar to the Call Butterfly but constructed with puts (K1 < K2 < K3). Expects the price to pin the middle strike (K2) at expiration. Defined risk, typically entered for a net debit. Profits from low volatility within a specific range.
threeLeg.notes: Strikes K1, K2, K3 are typically equidistant.

greeksImpact.gamma: Initially negative, becomes positive as price approaches K2, negative again beyond K2
greeksImpact.theta: Positive (benefits from time decay) when price is near K2, negative further away

threeLeg.maxProfit: Middle Strike (K2) - Lower Strike (K1) - Net Debit Paid
threeLeg.breakeven: Lower: K1 + Net Debit Paid; Upper: K3 - Net Debit Paid

threeLeg.name: Call Ratio Spread (Debit/Credit)
threeLeg.description: Buying a call option at a lower strike (K1) and selling a greater number of call options at a higher strike (K2) with the same expiration. Profits from a moderate move up towards K2. Faces significant, potentially unlimited risk if the price moves sharply above the higher strike (K2). Can be entered for a net debit or credit depending on strikes and premiums.
threeLeg.notes: K1 < K2. Common ratio is 1:2, but can vary. Risk is heavily skewed to the upside.

greeksImpact.delta: Positive below K2, turns negative above K2
greeksImpact.gamma: Initially positive, turns strongly negative above K2
greeksImpact.theta: Positive (benefits from time decay) when price is below K2, can become negative if price moves far above K2
greeksImpact.vega: Mixed, can be negative or positive depending on pricing and distance to strikes.

threeLeg.maxProfit: (K2 - K1) + Net Credit (if credit) or (K2 - K1) - Net Debit (if debit). Max profit is achieved exactly at strike K2.
threeLeg.breakeven: Lower: K1 + Net Debit/Credit (if debit, add; if credit, subtract). Upper: Calculated based on strikes, ratio, and net cost. Formula for 1:2 ratio: (2*K2 - K1) + Net Credit (or - Net Debit).

threeLeg.name: Put Ratio Spread (Debit/Credit)
threeLeg.description: Selling fewer puts at a higher strike (K2) than puts bought at a lower strike (K1) with the same expiration (K1 < K2). Profits from a moderate move down towards K1. Faces significant, potentially unlimited risk if the price moves sharply below the lower strike (K1). Can be entered for a net debit or credit.
threeLeg.notes: K1 < K2. Common ratio is 1:2, but can vary. Risk is heavily skewed to the downside.

greeksImpact.delta: Negative above K1, turns positive below K1
greeksImpact.gamma: Initially negative, turns strongly positive below K1
greeksImpact.theta: Positive (benefits from time decay) when price is above K1, can become negative if price moves far below K1
greeksImpact.vega: Mixed, can be negative or positive depending on pricing and distance to strikes.

threeLeg.maxProfit: (K2 - K1) + Net Credit (if credit) or (K2 - K1) - Net Debit (if debit). Max profit is achieved exactly at strike K1.
threeLeg.breakeven: Lower: Calculated based on strikes, ratio, and net cost. Formula for 1:2 ratio: (2*K1 - K2) + Net Credit (or - Net Debit). Upper: K2 - Net Debit/Credit (if debit, subtract; if credit, add).
threeLeg.example: Sell 1 MES JUN13 5970 Put for 104.50 (Bid), Buy 2 MES JUN13 5950 Puts for 105.00 (Ask) each. Net Debit: (2 * 105.00) - 104.50 = 210.00 - 104.50 = 105.50. Max Profit (at 5950): (5970 - 5950) - 105.50 = 20 - 105.50 = -85.50 (This example results in a max loss at the peak profit point due to the debit paid - highlights the impact of bid/ask). Upper Break-even: 5970 - 105.50 = 5864.50. Lower Break-even: (2 * 5950 - 5970) - 105.50 = (11900 - 5970) - 105.50 = 5930 - 105.50 = 5824.50.

threeLeg.name: Call Backspread (Ratio)
threeLeg.description: Selling a smaller number of calls at a lower strike (K1) and buying a larger number of calls at a higher strike (K2) with the same expiration (K1 < K2). Profits from a strong move to the upside beyond K2. Offers potentially unlimited profit if the price moves sharply higher. Can have a net debit or credit.
threeLeg.notes: K1 < K2. Common ratio is 1:2, but can vary. This is the inverse of a Call Ratio Spread.

greeksImpact.delta: Positive, increases as price moves up
greeksImpact.gamma: Positive, especially above K2
greeksImpact.theta: Negative (cost of holding the long options)

threeLeg.maxLoss: Limited (Occurs between K1 and K2, specifically at the Upper Break-even point)
threeLeg.breakeven: Lower: K1 + Net Debit (if debit) or K1 - Net Credit (if credit). Upper: Calculated based on strikes, ratio, and net cost. Formula for 1:2 ratio: (2*K2 - K1) + Net Credit (or - Net Debit).
threeLeg.example: Sell 1 MES JUN13 5970 Call for 83.25 (Bid), Buy 2 MES JUN13 5990 Calls for 78.00 (Ask) each. Net Debit: (2 * 78.00) - 83.25 = 156.00 - 83.25 = 72.75. Max Loss (at Upper Break-even): 72.75. Lower Break-even: 5970 + 72.75 = 6042.75. Upper Break-even: (2 * 5990 - 5970) - 72.75 = 6010 - 72.75 = 5937.25. (Break-evens can sometimes be counter-intuitive with debit backspreads).

threeLeg.name: Put Backspread (Ratio)
threeLeg.description: Selling a smaller number of puts at a higher strike (K2) and buying a larger number of puts at a lower strike (K1) with the same expiration (K1 < K2). Profits from a strong move to the downside below K1. Offers potentially unlimited profit if the price moves sharply lower. Can have a net debit or credit.
threeLeg.notes: K1 < K2. Common ratio is 1:2, but can vary. This is the inverse of a Put Ratio Spread.

greeksImpact.delta: Negative, becomes more negative as price moves down
greeksImpact.gamma: Positive, especially below K1
greeksImpact.theta: Negative (cost of holding the long options)

threeLeg.maxLoss: Limited (Occurs between K1 and K2, specifically at the Lower Break-even point)
threeLeg.breakeven: Lower: Calculated based on strikes, ratio, and net cost. Formula for 1:2 ratio: (2*K1 - K2) + Net Credit (or - Net Debit). Upper: K2 - Net Debit (if debit) or K2 + Net Credit (if credit).
threeLeg.example: Sell 1 MES JUN13 5970 Put for 104.50 (Bid), Buy 2 MES JUN13 5950 Puts for 105.00 (Ask) each. Net Debit: (2 * 105.00) - 104.50 = 210.00 - 104.50 = 105.50. Max Loss (at Lower Break-even): 105.50. Upper Break-even: 5970 - 105.50 = 5864.50. Lower Break-even: (2 * 5950 - 5970) - 105.50 = 5930 - 105.50 = 5824.50. (Break-evens can sometimes be counter-intuitive with debit backspreads).

fourLeg.name: Iron Condor (Credit)
fourLeg.description: A popular defined-risk, defined-profit strategy that benefits from time decay and low volatility. It involves selling an OTM Put Spread (K1 buy, K2 sell) and an OTM Call Spread (K3 sell, K4 buy). The goal is for the underlying price to remain between the short strikes (K2 and K3) at expiration. Typically entered for a net credit.
construction: Sell 1 OTM Put (Lower Short Strike - K2)
Sell 1 OTM Call (Upper Short Strike - K3)
fourLeg.notes: K1 < K2 < Current Price < K3 < K4. Wings (K2-K1 and K4-K3) are often equal width for symmetry. Max profit is the net credit.

greeksImpact.gamma: Negative (becomes more negative as price approaches short strikes)

fourLeg.maxLoss: Width of Widest Spread - Net Credit Received
fourLeg.breakeven: Lower: K2 - Net Credit Received; Upper: K3 + Net Credit Received
fourLeg.example: Buy 1 MES JUN13 5940 Put for 96.50 (Ask), Sell 1 MES JUN13 5960 Put for 100.00 (Bid), Sell 1 MES JUN13 5990 Call for 73.00 (Bid), Buy 1 MES JUN13 6010 Call for 68.50 (Ask). Net Credit: (100.00 + 73.00) - (96.50 + 68.50) = 173.00 - 165.00 = 8.00. Max Loss (assuming 20 point wings): 20 - 8.00 = 12.00. Lower Break-even: 5960 - 8.00 = 5952.00. Upper Break-even: 5990 + 8.00 = 5998.00.

fourLeg.name: Iron Butterfly (Credit)
fourLeg.description: A defined-risk, defined-profit strategy expecting minimal price movement and aiming for the underlying to expire exactly at the middle (short) strike (K2). It combines a short ATM straddle (selling ATM put and ATM call at K2) with protective OTM wings (buying a lower put at K1 and a higher call at K3). Offers higher potential profit (credit) than an Iron Condor but requires a narrower price range. Typically entered for a net credit.
fourLeg.notes: K1 < K2 < K3. Wings (K2-K1 and K3-K2) are often equidistant. K2 is typically ATM or very near.

greeksImpact.gamma: Strongly negative (becomes very negative as price moves away from K2)
greeksImpact.theta: Strongly positive (benefits significantly from time decay)
greeksImpact.vega: Strongly negative (loses value significantly with increased volatility)

fourLeg.maxLoss: Width of one Wing (e.g., K2 - K1) - Net Credit Received
fourLeg.breakeven: Lower: K2 - Net Credit Received; Upper: K2 + Net Credit Received
fourLeg.example: Buy 1 MES JUN13 5950 Put for 100.75 (Ask), Sell 1 MES JUN13 5970 Put for 104.50 (Bid), Sell 1 MES JUN13 5970 Call for 83.25 (Bid), Buy 1 MES JUN13 5990 Call for 78.00 (Ask). Net Credit: (104.50 + 83.25) - (100.75 + 78.00) = 187.75 - 178.75 = 9.00. Max Loss (assuming 20 point wings): (5970 - 5950) - 9.00 = 20 - 9.00 = 11.00. Lower Break-even: 5970 - 9.00 = 5961.00. Upper Break-even: 5970 + 9.00 = 5979.00.

fourLeg.name: Reverse Iron Condor (Long Iron Condor)
fourLeg.description: A defined-risk strategy that profits from a significant price move in either direction (increased volatility). It's the opposite of a standard Iron Condor, constructed by buying the OTM Put Spread (K2 buy, K1 sell) and buying the OTM Call Spread (K3 buy, K4 sell). This results in a net debit.
construction: Buy 1 OTM Put (Lower Short Strike - K2)
Buy 1 OTM Call (Upper Short Strike - K3)
fourLeg.notes: K1 < K2 < Current Price < K3 < K4. Opposite legs compared to standard Iron Condor. Profits occur when the price moves significantly outside the range of the short strikes (K2 & K3).

greeksImpact.gamma: Positive (becomes more positive as price moves away from short strikes)

fourLeg.maxProfit: Width of Widest Spread - Net Debit Paid (This is the theoretical maximum payoff *at the wings*, not necessarily the absolute max profit which is unlimited or substantial outside the wings).
fourLeg.breakeven: Lower: K2 + Net Debit Paid; Upper: K3 - Net Debit Paid
fourLeg.example: Sell 1 MES JUN13 5940 Put for 91.50 (Bid), Buy 1 MES JUN13 5960 Put for 105.00 (Ask), Buy 1 MES JUN13 5990 Call for 78.00 (Ask), Sell 1 MES JUN13 6010 Call for 63.75 (Bid). Net Debit: (105.00 + 78.00) - (91.50 + 63.75) = 183.00 - 155.25 = 27.75. Max Loss: 27.75. Lower Break-even: 5960 + 27.75 = 5987.75. Upper Break-even: 5990 - 27.75 = 5962.25. (Note break-evens are *between* the short strikes, profit is *outside*).

fourLeg.name: Box Spread (Long)
fourLeg.description: Not a directional or volatility play. Combines a Bull Call Spread (Buy K1 Call, Sell K2 Call) and a Bear Put Spread (Buy K2 Put, Sell K1 Put) using the same two strikes (K1 < K2) and same expiration. Theoretically locks in a risk-free profit equal to the difference between strikes minus the net debit paid. In practice, arbitrage opportunities are rare due to commissions and bid-ask spreads. Often used for financing purposes (creating a synthetic loan or deposit). The payoff at expiration is always K2 - K1.
fourLeg.notes: All options must have the same expiration. Payoff at expiration is fixed at K2 - K1.

greeksImpact.gamma: Zero

fourLeg.maxLoss: Net Debit Paid - (K2 - K1) (if positive, usually near zero or small loss after costs)
fourLeg.breakeven: N/A (Payoff is constant at K2 - K1. Profit/Loss determined solely by initial cost vs. K2-K1).
fourLeg.example: Buy 1 MES JUN13 5960 Call for 93.75 (Ask), Sell 1 MES JUN13 5970 Call for 83.25 (Bid), Buy 1 MES JUN13 5970 Put for 109.50 (Ask), Sell 1 MES JUN13 5960 Put for 100.00 (Bid). Net Debit: (93.75 + 109.50) - (83.25 + 100.00) = 203.25 - 183.25 = 20.00. Value at Expiration = 5970 - 5960 = 10. Profit = 10 - 20.00 = -10.00. (This example shows a loss due to bid-ask spread).

fourLeg.name: Short Call Condor (Credit)
fourLeg.description: Defined-risk, defined-profit strategy selling two inner calls (K2, K3) and buying two outer calls (K1, K4) with the same expiration (K1 < K2 < K3 < K4). Profits if the underlying price stays between K2 and K3 at expiration. Similar payoff to a Short Strangle but with defined risk. Typically entered for a net credit.
fourLeg.notes: K1 < K2 < K3 < K4, often equidistant strikes. K2 and K3 are typically near current price or OTM.

greeksImpact.gamma: Negative (most negative between K2 and K3)

fourLeg.maxLoss: Width of one Wing (K2 - K1 or K4 - K3) - Net Credit Received
fourLeg.breakeven: Lower: K2 - Net Credit Received; Upper: K3 + Net Credit Received
fourLeg.example: Buy 1 MES JUN13 5950 Call for 99.25 (Ask), Sell 1 MES JUN13 5970 Call for 83.25 (Bid), Sell 1 MES JUN13 5980 Call for 78.00 (Bid), Buy 1 MES JUN13 6000 Call for 73.25 (Ask). Net Debit: (99.25 + 73.25) - (83.25 + 78.00) = 172.50 - 161.25 = 11.25. (Note: This example results in a Net Debit based on MES data. A typical credit condor would have a credit). Max Loss (assuming 20 point wings): 20 - (-11.25) = 31.25 (Since it's a debit, max profit is -11.25 between K2 & K3, and max loss occurs outside the wings). Break-even: 5970 - (-11.25) = 5981.25, 5980 + (-11.25) = 5968.75. (Break-evens are outside K2 & K3 when it's a debit condor).

fourLeg.name: Long Call Condor (Debit)
fourLeg.description: Defined-risk strategy buying two inner calls (K2, K3) and selling two outer calls (K1, K4) with the same expiration (K1 < K2 < K3 < K4). Profits if the underlying price moves significantly outside the range of the inner strikes (K2 and K3). The opposite of a Short Call Condor. Typically entered for a net debit.
fourLeg.notes: K1 < K2 < K3 < K4, often equidistant strikes. K2 and K3 are typically near current price or OTM. Risk is limited to the debit paid.

greeksImpact.gamma: Positive (most positive between K2 and K3)

fourLeg.maxProfit: Width of one Wing (K2 - K1 or K4 - K3) - Net Debit Paid (This is the profit at the wings, not the potential outside)
fourLeg.breakeven: Lower: K1 + Net Debit Paid; Upper: K4 - Net Debit Paid
fourLeg.example: Sell 1 MES JUN13 5950 Call for 95.75 (Bid), Buy 1 MES JUN13 5970 Call for 88.25 (Ask), Buy 1 MES JUN13 5980 Call for 83.00 (Ask), Sell 1 MES JUN13 6000 Call for 73.25 (Bid). Net Debit: (88.25 + 83.00) - (95.75 + 73.25) = 171.25 - 169.00 = 2.25. Max Loss: 2.25. Break-even: 5950 + 2.25 = 5952.25, 6000 - 2.25 = 5997.75.

fourLeg.name: Short Put Condor (Credit)
fourLeg.description: Defined-risk strategy selling two inner puts (K2, K3) and buying two outer puts (K1, K4) with the same expiration (K1 < K2 < K3 < K4). Profits if the underlying price stays between K2 and K3 at expiration. Similar payoff to a Short Strangle but with defined risk. Typically entered for a net credit.
fourLeg.notes: K1 < K2 < K3 < K4, often equidistant strikes. K2 and K3 are typically near current price or OTM.

greeksImpact.gamma: Negative (most negative between K2 and K3)

fourLeg.maxLoss: Width of one Wing (K2 - K1 or K4 - K3) - Net Credit Received
fourLeg.breakeven: Lower: K2 - Net Credit Received; Upper: K3 + Net Credit Received
fourLeg.example: Buy 1 MES JUN13 5940 Put for 96.50 (Ask), Sell 1 MES JUN13 5960 Put for 100.00 (Bid), Sell 1 MES JUN13 5970 Put for 104.50 (Bid), Buy 1 MES JUN13 5990 Put for 119.25 (Ask). Net Debit: (96.50 + 119.25) - (100.00 + 104.50) = 215.75 - 204.50 = 11.25. (Note: This example results in a Net Debit based on MES data. A typical credit condor would have a credit). Max Loss (assuming 20 point wings): 20 - (-11.25) = 31.25. Break-even: 5960 - (-11.25) = 5971.25, 5970 + (-11.25) = 5958.75. (Break-evens are outside K2 & K3 when it's a debit condor).

fourLeg.name: Long Put Condor (Debit)
fourLeg.description: Defined-risk strategy buying two inner puts (K2, K3) and selling two outer puts (K1, K4) with the same expiration (K1 < K2 < K3 < K4). Profits if the underlying price moves significantly outside the range of the inner strikes (K2 and K3). The opposite of a Short Put Condor. Typically entered for a net debit.
fourLeg.notes: K1 < K2 < K3 < K4, often equidistant strikes. K2 and K3 are typically near current price or OTM. Risk is limited to the debit paid.

greeksImpact.gamma: Positive (most positive between K2 and K3)

fourLeg.maxProfit: Width of one Wing (K2 - K1 or K4 - K3) - Net Debit Paid (This is the profit at the wings, not the potential outside)
fourLeg.breakeven: Lower: K1 + Net Debit Paid; Upper: K4 - Net Debit Paid

about.title: About This Tool
content: This page provides information and payoff diagrams for various option strategies, categorized by the number of 'legs' (individual option contracts) involved.
The examples use MES (Micro E-mini S&P 500) option prices from the provided screenshot (June 13, 2025 expiration data) for illustration where possible.
Prices used for examples are based on the Bid (for sells) and Ask (for buys) from the provided image table. Actual execution prices may vary.
The payoff diagrams illustrate the theoretical profit or loss of each strategy *at expiration* based on the price of the underlying asset. They are generated using Plotly.js.

Please note that real-world premiums vary based on volatility, time to expiration, interest rates, and market conditions. The bid/ask spread can significantly impact the actual cost or credit received, as seen in some examples resulting in a debit where the strategy description typically implies a credit.

Greeks (Delta, Gamma, Theta, Vega) describe how an option's price changes in response to changes in the underlying price, volatility, time, and interest rates. Understanding Greeks helps manage the risk of a strategy over its life, not just at expiration.

Disclaimer: This information is strictly for educational purposes and does not constitute financial advice. Option trading involves significant risk and is not suitable for all investors. Consult with a qualified financial professional before trading options.
